description: Does what is intended.
Finally a tray workaround for TB! Many thanks! My only issues are that: 1) the app cannot run local binaries (from /usr/bin for example), and the app crashes when closed after TB is closed first.

I'm running Debian 10 + Gnome 3.30.2 and I needed to start Birdtray from the command-line this way:

  flatpak run --own-name='org.kde.*' com.ulduzsoft.Birdtray

Maybe unrelated, but I also ran this command: `export -n SESSION_MANAGER`. I have no idea if it's required and what it does.. Use it at your own risk!

Is it clunky? Yes. Does it break? Sometimes. Is it the best option we've got? Yup. Thanks for making it. Side note: It appears to be much more responsive/better experience on KDE than back when I used it on GNOME a month or two ago. Could be due to updates, or the way KDE handles tray icons.

Works fine as a tray app, pulls up Thunderbird, hides it... but.

It will only auto-launch the Flatpak version of Thunderbird, which is fine. However, it will not display unread notification count, or blink when there are unread emails, with the Flatpak version. It only does this with the RPM version for me. 

Meanwhile, on the RPM version, it will only successfully hide-on-minimize the first few times, then fail until you manually restart Thunderbird.

So, you sort of have to pick your poison. Do you want to be able to auto-start Thunderbird, but lose out on the tray icon providing any useful information at all? Or do you want to get useful information but be unable to auto-hide and auto-start Thunderbird?
summary: Does what it is meant to, but additional features are hit or miss
